table.name: Antronec Exploration; Antronec Sewers Random Secret Entrance
rows: Tracing a caravan route on a map with a finger activates a series of buttons that open that section of the wall.
A broken chair in the back of a store can be rotated, revealing a trap door.
A torch sconce or candle holder can be pulled down, opening a tunnel in the wall.
One of the bookshelves has a specific book that can make it swing ajar when pulled out.
The series of 'decorative' levers can be pulled in a pattern, activating a small elevator.
An empty but massive barrel in the cellar can be shifted to reveal the hole below it.
The metal grate that sawdust is swept down into can be removed, accessing a gently sloping tunnel.
A decorative ship's wheel can be turned in a specific pattern to unlock a trap door beneath a nearby rug.
Behind a large, ugly painting lies a small doorway.
One of the bricks in the wall can be pushed to open a hidden door.
One of the many ovens, while not in use, has a large flue that leads down as well as up the chimney.
Under one of the many workbenches, a switch activates a folding staircase.

table.name: Antronec Exploration; Antronec Sewers Random Encounter
rows: {@dice 2d4} guild {@creature spy|MM|spies} ({@chance 50|50%}) or {@dice 3d4} {@creature cartographers's agent|GriffonsSaddlebag2|cartographers's agents} (see appendix A) ({@chance 50|50%}) that don't want to leave witnesses (see {@table Antronec Adventure Hooks; Random Guild|GriffonsSaddlebag2|Random Guild Table})
A disguised sewer-filth trap releases gushing waste. Each character must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 2d6} poison damage and become {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour.
{@dice 1d4} {@creature giant spore lizard|GriffonsSaddlebag2|giant spore lizards} (see appendix A)

A bag of {@dice 6d8} copper pieces with {@dice 1d6} {@creature seed coin|GriffonsSaddlebag2|seed coins} (see appendix A) mixed in ({@chance 60|60%}) or {@dice 1d3} {@creature germination stall|GriffonsSaddlebag2|germination stalls} (see appendix A) ({@chance 40|40%})

{@dice 4d4} {@creature rat|MM|rats} ({@chance 40|40%}), {@dice 2d4} {@creature giant rat|MM|giant rats} ({@chance 30|30%}), or {@dice 1d4} {@creature giant spider rat|GriffonsSaddlebag2|giant spider rats} (see appendix A) ({@chance 30|30%})
{@dice 3d6} corpses of guild members, roughly {@dice 1d6} weeks old (see {@table Antronec Adventure Hooks; Random Guild|GriffonsSaddlebag2|Random Guild Table})
A secret sewer offshoot tunnel that contains an ancient relic, hidden and forgotten decades ago.
A hidden or abandoned workshop belonging to a random guild (see {@table Antronec Adventure Hooks; Random Guild|GriffonsSaddlebag2|Random Guild Table})

table.name: Antronec Adventure Hooks; Random Guild
rows: The League of Bricks and Mortar

table.name: Antronec Adventure Hooks; Random Desire or Fear
rows: A design, patent, or blueprint for an invention capable of revolutionizing Antronec
A large amount of coin being transferred between safe-houses or banks
Evidence of a covered-up business mistake that could spell disaster for the person responsible
A spy within a guild was discovered and is now being interrogated
News that a shop only has one supplier left, making them easy to buy out or blackmail
An influx of cheap materials or tools flooding the market
Collusion, trade between guilds without passing through the Merchant's Guild first
A previously-ousted Guildmaster planning to get back into the fray

table.name: Antronec Adventure Hooks; Random Interference
rows: Dispatch an elite squad of mercenaries, adventurers, or assassins
Enlist a skilled thief to procure a vital item
Blackmail the most powerful person involved
Raze a warehouse or storefront to send a message
Kidnap and ransom their opponent's family member or close friend
Vandalize an important or expensive property

table.name: Making Custom Antronec Guild NPCs; Personality Traits
rows: I easily get distracted by the small details of life, losing track of the big picture.
I'm incredibly competitive with the crafters within my own guild.
I speak far too quickly, as I'm eager to finish conversations and return to work.
To cover my lack of artistic flair, I have to absolutely gush with charm and suave salesmanship.
I'm such a horrible liar that I never make as much profit as others do.
I'm a horribly brusque businessperson, but I stick with it because of my devotion to the art.

table.name: Making Custom Antronec Guild NPCs; Ideals
rows: {@b Perfection.} I cannot permit even one imperfection to spoil my craft. (Lawful)
{@b Self-improvement.} If each project is better than the last, my life is worthwhile. (Good)
{@b Beauty.} A true crafter brings utility and artistic wonder into the world. (Good)
{@b Hard Work.} I may not be as talented as others, but I compensate by giving all of my effort. (Lawful)
{@b Ambition.} I care about success, and in Antronec, the gateway is climbing the Guild ranks. (Any)
{@b Change.} A significant portion of art is how it changes the world, for better or worse. I want my work to move civilizations and mountains. (Chaotic)

table.name: Making Custom Antronec Guild NPCs; Bonds
rows: I've invested a lifetime of effort into my business, growing it from the ground up.
A fellow Guild crafter was my mentor, they taught me everything I know about the craft.
Now that I can't work as much, I've taken on a number of skilled apprentices. They will be my legacy.
The craft itself is everything to me. If I had no outlet for my artistic vision, I'd have nothing worth living for.
I pour a piece of my soul into each piece I make. My life's work and I are one and the same.
{@homebrew Reroll.|No 6th option was present in source on this table, adding reroll since there wasn't anything.}

table.name: Making Custom Antronec Guild NPCs; Flaws
rows: I'm certain that people are plotting against me, making it difficult to trust others.
I've done horrible things to attain my position, and am plagued by my guilt. Should anyone uncover my deeds, I'd be ruined.
I can never work hard enough, fast enough, good enough to compete with my rival in the guild, and the frustration makes my temper short.
In pursuit of wealth, I take reckless risks I probably shouldn't, but can't resist.
I'm so focused upon my future ambitions and goals, that I'm blind to those I trample on my path forward.
My cutthroat business dealings have whittled away what few emotions and cares I had in the world, making me overwhelmingly cynical.

table.name: Bloodmire Diseases
rows: Bloodburnt Rash: At the start of each of your turns when you are not under the bloodwater, you take {@damage 1d6} fire damage. This disease lasts until you take fire damage equal to half your hit point maximum in this way.

Crimson Sight: Your eyes become bloodshot, your pupils dilate, and your senses of safety and danger become twisted. Whenever you see a fey or humanoid, flip a coin. If it's heads, you consider that creature to be a friendly acquaintance. If it's tails, you consider the creature to be a hostile enemy. You consider any fiend or fiendish villager to be a friendly acquaintance, even if it's under the effect of illusory magic. This disease lasts until you finish a long rest.

Rusting Flesh: Sometimes called the Iron Curse, this disease causes your flesh to corrode and slough off. You take {@damage 1d8} necrotic damage and your maximum hit points are reduced by the same amount each day at dusk. If your hit point maximum drops to 0 in this way, you die. This disease lasts until 7 days have passed.

Blood Lunacy: A rare and weakened form of lycanthropy. You suffer disadvantage on saving throws against contracting lycanthropy. Your hair begins to grow long and thick, and you gain no benefit from finishing a short or long rest during a full moon. This disease lasts until it's cured by magical means.

table.name: Bloodmire Exploration; Bloodmire Navigation DCs
rows: A location in the outskirts of the Bloodmire, or near an outpost
A location near the center of the mire, such as the Verdant Heart.
A location hidden from view, such as a sprite village, secret island, or forgotten fey portal.

table.name: Bloodmire Exploration; Becoming Lost
rows: Amid backtracking and great confusion, the party ends the day up to {@dice 2d6} miles in a random direction away from their destination if sailing, or {@dice 1d6} miles away if walking.
Using the gradual current of blood emanating from the Verdant Heart, the party ends the day up to {@dice 1d6} miles away from their destination despite being lost.

table.name: Bloodmire Exploration; Diseased Foraged Food
rows: The character is {@condition poisoned} for 8 hours and rolls on the {@table Bloodmire Diseases|GriffonsSaddlebag2|Bloodmire disease} table.
The character is {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour.
The character is not nourished but suffers no other ill effects.

table.name: Bloodmire Exploration; Encounters
rows: A corrupted fey portal that allows instant travel to a realm of shadows and dread during the new moon.
A hidden, quicksand-like pool of diseased blood. Each character must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become diseased (see {@table Bloodmire Diseases|GriffonsSaddlebag2} table).

{@dice 1d4} carnivorous plants. The same number of characters must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or suffer {@damage 2d8} slashing damage and become diseased (see {@table Bloodmire Diseases|GriffonsSaddlebag2} table) as the plants' vines slice into exposed flesh.
A grove of abundant bloodfern. Spending 1 hour gathering yields {@dice 1d4} pounds per character, up to a maximum of 30 pounds.
A fallen bloodbark tree. Spending 1 hour with an axe yields {@dice 2d12} pounds per character, up to a maximum of 48 pounds.

{@dice 1d4} {@creature giant mosquitoe|GriffonsSaddlebag2|giant mosquitoes} (see appendix B) ({@chance 60|60%}) or {@creature swarm of giant mosquitoes|GriffonsSaddlebag2|swarms of giant mosquitoes} (see appendix B) ({@chance 40|40%})
{@dice 1d3} {@creature giant blood eel|GriffonsSaddlebag2|giant blood eels} (see appendix B)
{@dice 3d4} {@creature giant frog|MM|giant frogs} ({@chance 50|50%}) or {@creature giant poisonous snake|MM|giant snakes} ({@chance 50|50%})
{@dice 2d6} fugitives ({@creature outlaw|GriffonsSaddlebag2|outlaws}) hunting for food. They leave peacefully if given rations/supplies, but otherwise attack.
{@dice 1d4} {@creature Crimson Legion Imp|GriffonsSaddlebag2|Crimson Legion imps} (see appendix B) prowling for violence.
A dense cloud of diseased insects. Each character must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or become diseased (see {@table Bloodmire Diseases|GriffonsSaddlebag2} table).

Old fey ruins buried under mud and submerged in the swamp. Murals of the war ({@chance 75|75%}) or carved poetry about Syre ({@chance 25|25%}) can be found with a DC 17 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check.
A battlefield from the war. Fey and fiendish weapons and armor long corroded ({@chance 90|90%}) or intact ({@chance 10|10%}).
A partially submerged fey monument depicting a bold warrior. A successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check recognizes the ancient hero as Syre.
{@dice 1d8} {@creature sprite|MM|sprites} out scouting in secret for intelligence (Reroll if the party is far away from the Verdant Heart).
An intact fey portal that allows instant travel to the sprite village in the Verdant Heart while a waxing crescent moon is overhead.

table.name: Bloodmire Exploration; Example Dungeons
rows: Hidden and carefully guarded under the bloodwater of a Crimson Legion village is an alchemical laboratory that contains a stockpile of broken fey orbs. Careful investigation could reveal the history of these orbs as well as a way to disable them.

A once-prominent fortress built by Syre and his warriors is now almost completely destroyed by plantlife, mud, and bloodwater. The sturdy yet sunken walls are now home to a variety of monstrous amphibians, reptiles, and other beasts. Perhaps some carved hints about the Bloodmire's origin or ancient artifacts could be salvaged.

High in the canopy, a large number of giant mosquitoes have made a strange hive that's reminiscent of a wasp's nest. Local refugees weren't concerned about the hive until the insects started abducting children and small adults. They suspect that the people stolen are being used to build, or possibly feed, something deep within the hive's tunnels.

One of the very few intact fey portals leads to Syre's hidden demiplane: a tower filled with magical traps, libraries, and fey heirlooms. Whether led there by sprites or found by chance, only the bravest adventurers would be capable of journeying to the end to find the mysterious treasure Syre left behind. However, even the few remaining sprites can't remember what it might be.

A fey portal has become corrupted by the Bloodmire's curses. Each new moon, the portal sparks to life and allows travel to a realm full of shades, dark magic, and terrors of the night. While it's open, this portal allows these strange nightmares to leak out and terrorize the swamp's inhabitants with otherworldly monsters. Unless someone can find a way to close the portal, the Bloodmire may fall completely under its sway.

Rumor tells that a group of bandits have amassed a hoard of treasure somewhere in the Bloodmire that's filled with gold, goods, and supplies stolen from merchants who were careless or desperate enough to travel through the swamp unprotected.

table.name: Crest City; Weather Patterns
intro: Part of Lothrem's influence over the city is directly tied to his mood. With the exception of the afternoon rainshower, you can determine Lothrem's current mood and the city's weather using the following table.

table.name: Crest City Exploration; Warrens Encounters
rows: An ore vein of copper ({@chance 50|50%}), silver ({@chance 30|30%}), gold ({@chance 15|15%}), or platinum ({@chance 5|5%})
{@dice 1d4} {@creature gelatinous cube|MM|gelatinous cubes} ({@chance 80|80%}) or 1 {@creature black pudding|MM} ({@chance 20|20%})
An ancient ruined monument depicting a large hatching egg, strangely warm to the touch.

table.name: Making Custom Druid NPCs; Personality Traits
rows: I struggle to control the drive to hoard wealth while in dragon form.
I'm constantly driven to keep things around me clean and orderly.
I have a nasty habit of snacking on rodents while in dragon form.
I always have change jangling in my pockets.
I hate that there are secrets I'm not allowed to know.
I often find my facial expressions to be unintentionally stoic or intimidating.
Random trivia is the coinage for my intellectual hoard.
I'm always more confident and comfortable when transformed.

table.name: Making Custom Druid NPCs; Ideals
rows: Justice. It's a lifestyle I take seriously. (Lawful)
Wisdom. Our way of life requires the constant advice of our forebears. (Neutral)
Responsibility. As a member of this proud tradition, I must strive for excellence. (Lawful)
Knowledge. The Circle's success thrives on secrets and research. (Neutral)
Order. Society would crumble without the Circle's firm guiding hand. (Lawful)
Patience. The Circle must patiently reap, that we may eventually sow. (Any)

table.name: Making Custom Druid NPCs; Bonds
rows: I witnessed a horrible act from a corrupt member of the Circle, but have no proof.
I seek to recover my family's tome of lineage, lost two generations ago.
I have a long-standing rivalry with another member of the Circle.
A mentor of the Circle took me in as a youth, I owe them everything.
An innocent family member is imprisoned in the Penitentiary.
I've been charged by the Spire to seek out arcane knowledge.

table.name: Making Custom Druid NPCs; Flaws
rows: I am so accustomed to lying and keeping secrets that I struggle to tell the truth.
I struggle to prevent myself from immediately executing judgment when I witness a crime.
I'm so focused on gathering knowledge that I find it painful to share it with others.
My exacting standards of self-perfection drive me to the brink of exhaustion on a daily basis.
I would set the world ablaze if tasked to do so by the Circle.
I truly believe that the world would be better off under the control of dragons instead of mortals.

table.name: Durheim Monastery; Ethereal Random Encounter Table
rows: A {@creature The Wild Hunt|GriffonsSaddlebag2|Wild Hunt} (see Durheim Stat Blocks)
{@dice 1d4} {@creature haunted reflection|MM|haunted reflections} (see Durheim Stat Blocks)
{@dice 1d2} {@creature death coach|GriffonsSaddlebag2|death coaches} (see Durheim Stat Blocks)
A {@creature ghost dragon|GriffonsSaddlebag2} (see Durheim Stat Blocks)

table.name: Durheim Monastery Adeventure Hooks
rows: After a series of mysterious murders that seem to repeat a specific pattern from 50 years ago, the party hears about the Durheim Monastery's extensive Library of Life. Perhaps the insights there will aid in identifying the past and present killers.

An acquaintance of the party asks for help, explaining that they're being haunted by a vengeful ghost. They claim ignorance as to why they're being targeted, so only a thorough investigation will reveal the truth.
A lonely child speaks of an imaginary friend but is mocked by others for such a thing. A number of "accidents" are befalling those who dare speak ill of the child's companion.
The party is contracted by a retired adventurer who is being hunted by the spirits of every monster and villain they ever fought.
Several normally peaceful townsfolk are in jail for crimes they don't remember committing. The victims all seem to have links to the local nobility.
A piece of loot turns out to be a vessel for the spirit of a lost and scared child. Standard methods of releasing them fail, but maybe the experts at Durheim can help.
One of the party members crosses into the Border Ethereal, leaving the rest of the party to find a means of crossing and retrieving them.

A succession war is brewing, but all the evidence hinges on the spoken testimony of a baroness. A Durheim monk Walking the Liminal Path recommends the party visit the monastery and consult the records of one or more past rulers that are contained within.

Over the past few months, a prominent nobleman has been targeted by no less than fifteen assassination attempts by spectral assailants. No matter how grisly or public these incidents appear to be, the noble continues to go about his business the following day.
The local gravekeeper has vanished, and his old hound has begun to terrorize anyone that tries to approach the cemetery, despite being quite docile in the past.

table.name: Making Custom Durheim NPCs; Personality Traits
rows: I'm infinitely optimistic about the potential redemption of every spirit, even those who cause great harm.
I enjoy the violent parts of hunting spirits too much but am striving to find peace with the aid of my fellow monks.
I've helped friends and family pass on, but am still deeply troubled and meditate often on the purpose of my own life.
I believe that every ethereal spirit that claims to be peaceful is nonetheless capable of causing harm, so I send them to their rest by whatever means necessary.
I'm terrified of ghosts, but I joined the order so that I can one day conquer my fear.
I was raised by the monastery, so I follow their rules and guidelines to the letter.

table.name: Making Custom Durheim NPCs; Ideals
rows: Order. Structure and manners are the key ingredients in the making of a good life. (Lawful)
Charity. Helping lost souls is a noble calling, and I fully embrace it. (Good)
Aspiration. I find joy in my work, and strive to be the best spiritual guide I possibly can. (Any)
Freedom. I struggle to follow the rules of the order, focusing instead on getting the job done. (Chaotic)
Honesty. I value truth above all, even if it hurts others' feelings. (Lawful)
Joy. I love to feel my spirits being lifted as I guide others to peace. (Good)

table.name: Making Custom Durheim NPCs; Bonds
rows: I joined the monastery seeking peace and now that I've found it, I'll defend it to the end.
I'm training hard so that one day, I will be able to find and release the lost soul of a family member.
I struggle to feel peace outside the monastery, it keeps me anchored.
I feel aimless whenever I return to the monastery—I feel most alive when I'm investigating a haunting.
The monastery guards the border between the Material and Ethereal Planes, preventing conflict wherever we can.
Everyone says I'm too fidgety to ever find inner peace through meditation, but I'm going to prove them wrong one day.

table.name: Making Custom Durheim NPCs; Flaws
rows: Growing up in the monastery, I've been sheltered from the outside world, so I'm a bit clueless about most social interactions.
I focus so much on the Ethereal Plane, I often lose track of or downright ignore events on the Material Plane.
My forays into deep meditation have left me feeling detached from my physical body, it sometimes feels like a burden.
I don't sleep often or well, due to nightmares about some of my more horrifying ghost hunts.
I've grown so accustomed to following my superiors' requests, that I sometimes struggle to think or act for myself.
I secretly long for the day I die, so that I can experience what it's like firsthand.

table.name: Taverns and Festivals; Random Locale
rows: On top of a floating rock above a boiling-hot lake
On the grounds of a long-abandoned manor that was originally home to a family of vampires
In an underwater cavern covered in bright coral
Inside of an old, abandoned wizard tower with some of its magical remnants still in effect
Within a living but hollowed-out tree, and its accompanying treehouse
On top of a lake that remains frozen year-round, regardless of the ambient temperature
In a long-abandoned and renovated temple to an unknown, dead deity
Floating across the sky on top of a cloud
Inside a labyrinthine network of caves and tunnels
In the hollowed-out space of a false hill or mountain
Carried aloft on a platform by a large menagerie of tamed, flying creatures
In the space below a verdant desert oasis
Inside a demiplane that can only be accessed by a single, wooden door that's carried around by the owner or other large creature
Carved into icy tundra permafrost and magically kept warm without melting the ice around it
In an abandoned, reinforced mine shaft
On top of a large, arched bridge that spans a vast white-water river
Floating in the middle of a swampy morass with enchantments that keep the insects at bay
In a massive warehouse, with enchanted platforms leading up, down, and around the interior
On top of a series of lashed-together barges floating along the coastline
Entirely underwater, with permanent enchantments to make the water breathable

table.name: Taverns and Festivals; Random Tavern or Festival
intro: You can use the following table to randomly select a fantastical tavern or mystical festival for your adventuring party to rest or celebrate in.
rows: {@b Lost Souls} is an eerily quiet establishment, known mostly for its odd sounds and whispers, floating cups, and silent but oft-moving doors.
{@b First Moon Festival} is the celebration of the first moon of the new year and is a symbol of new beginnings. Special lanterns and candles are lit as an offering for good luck for the year.
{@b The Unlucky Hare} prides itself on having the softest and finest pelts, hides, and furs to provide luxurious comfort and warmth for its patrons.
{@b Blue Moon Festival} is a high-class gathering of rare and bizarre items, as well as exclusive merchants who will only sell to those willing to pay their sometimes exorbitant entrance fees.
{@b Otyugh's Bane} is an immaculately kept business that employs many workers to keep things spick and span. Waste and refuse are magically removed as well.
{@b Lunar Eclipse Festival} is a day dedicated to warding against the encroaching shadow of an eclipse. Bonfires and fireworks are lit throughout the duration of the eclipse.
{@b The Left-Handed Knight} is known for the pieces of armor that cover the dings and dents in its walls, as the visitors often get out of hand.

{@b The Gluttonous Gourd Gathering} is a wandering caravan whose wagons are painted in deep oranges and greens. Whenever they set up near a settlement, they share their gardening secrets and homebrewed pumpkin ale over several nights.
{@b The Golden Lion} is a warm, multi-leveled tavern that has many large rooms for the adventuring parties that pass through the area.

{@b Singer's Strings} sets up shop along the outside of towns and cities, inviting the trade of story and songs. Contests of songs and performances are often rewarded with fine instruments and books of ballads.
{@b The Tone-Deaf Siren} is renowned for its wide variety of well-respected entertainers. At night, the hall is filled with music and dancing until the sun comes up.

{@b Feasts of the Fallen Stars} is a winter festival where visitors gather to eat a hearty supper under the light of annual shooting stars. The next day, the festival-goers search for the fallen meteors to collect for their rare materials.
{@b The Crossroads} seems to be the place for lost wanderers in the city, with its dark furniture only matching the shady deals made under its tables.

{@b Green Palm Week} is a week-long festival in which people work together in preparation for the growing season, cultivating fields and community gardens. At the end of the week, special events that reward the people for their work are held.
{@b The Leaping Chain} is carefully tucked along the side of a mountain, giving all who stay there a grand view of the land below.
{@b The Clarity} is a celebration marking the anniversary of when an ancient curse and its madness were lifted from the land.
{@b The Chromatic Scowl} proudly displays a large set of dragon fangs behind the bar, assembled from various sizes and colors of evil dragons.
{@b The Cavalcade} is a spectacular celebration in which people split into two groups and reenact a magical war by launching harmless, yet brilliant, fireworks at one another.
{@b The Howling Hall} is a wide lodge that often houses a dozen wolves at any point, with the pack trading their protection for the hall's housing.

{@b Hero's March} is a memorial celebration of legendary adventurers and their many heroic deeds. Locals dress up in elaborate costumes depicting their favorite heroes: typically ones who either originated from the area or performed a great service to them.
{@b The Tipsy Wyvern} is a tavern most known for its upside-down layout and eclectic decorations.
{@b The Tumbler's Traveling Troupe} is a motley collection of clowns and jesters that roll through towns bringing merriment and festivity.
{@b The Prophet's Garden} has walls covered in vines and flowers, with small patches of grass tucked into the corners, and a small pond filled with gem-like fish.
{@b Skye Carnival} began after a friendly cloud giant shared insight into flight, freedom, and the winds. During the event, colorful balloons and kites fill the sky.

table.name: Taverns and Festivals; Random Tavern Owner or Festival Host
intro: You can use the following table to randomly determine the proprietor of your tavern or festival.
rows: {@b Ilmis} is a female half-orc and former adventurer turned owner, who spent her life savings to buy her favorite tavern. She now offers respite for coin or story, as she's still excited to learn about lands she's never seen.

{@b Spark} is a reformed male tiefling arsonist that now utilizes extensive pyromantic light shows and fireworks to enhance his festival's other performances. He always ensures water is nearby, just in case.
{@b Alimorel Wyvernjack} is a large female human who owns an equally large tavern. With her greataxe hung up behind the bar, it is rumored she is part giant due to her height and strength.

{@b Frostjaw} is a rough-scaled and stern white dragonborn. A thoroughly organized leader, they run the festival like a ship. They even refer to employees as crew and often employ other nautical terms in conversation.
{@b Ashti} is a human man and ugly as the day is long, but has a charm that comes from his quick wit and quicker drinks. He's not opposed to a bribe to hide someone in a secret room.

{@b Karethia Brightlow} is a young female gnome that initially joined the circus as a trapeze artist. Over the years, she worked and became the owner. Her flexibility extends to planning and management.
{@b Okli} is a slim half-elven male with a wide smile and a hiss on his words. He welcomes all into his tavern but is quick to anger when a patron grows unreasonable.

{@b Briar Fen} is a human who remains sober and somber for most of the year but comes alive with vibrant energy whenever it's time for a festival. Their seemingly boundless energy in organizing the festivities is unparalleled.

{@b Kavon Brightwood} is an outgoing human tavern owner. He has a knack for remembering names, connecting like-minded visitors, and deducing truths from rumors and body language. He is a self-taught wizard and adds spells to his spellbook as drunken tavern-goers leave their spell scrolls and other arcane writings behind.
{@b Dematrias} is an ancient gold dragon who enjoys putting on events and festivals in unusual locations, assuming many different forms and names over the years in order to remain undetected.

{@b Neth'faris} is often mistaken as a quiet bookworm and is quick to sling a drink to a patron to return to reading. It's not unheard of unruly patrons suddenly running in fear from the tiefling after a few sharp, muttered words.

{@b Tylina Balefrost} is a centuries-old female elf who enjoys a good drink and a better tale. Her expensive tastes allow her to know exactly what is necessary for the highest quality production of an event, and never settles for less.
{@b Saye} is a large human with a deep laugh and deeper tankards. He keeps a small forest of potted plants in the tavern's storage rooms.
{@b Cristel Kelmys} is an older human lord infamous for his stuffy, invite-only parties where anyone who's anyone would kill, often literally, for the honor of attending it.

{@b Nysea} is a djinni who enjoys spending her time mixing strange, magical drinks to serve her unsuspecting patrons, causing all sorts of strange, sometimes unwanted effects. However, the drinks are cheap, which keeps her clientele coming back for more each day.
{@b Pyp} is a young satyr who enjoys tricks, pranks, and jokes. He's quick to apologize if his actions offend, but doesn't let that stop him from continuing his mischievous activities.
{@b Metto} is a stone giant that delights in serving smaller folk. They use delicate movements to avoid causing injury and studiously record the life stories of those who are willing to share.
{@b Torrdok the Magnificent} is a half-orc illusionist that specializes in elaborate glamours and enchantments. He delights in creating fabulous mirages and bursts of color to delight the senses.

{@b Meeplin Leafjaw} is an ambitious but amateur halfling brewer that uses the tavern's income to fund their culinary experiments. They're all for sale at the tavern's bar, but most avoid them due to their unpredictable results.

{@b Sir Feren Olefson} is a retired human knight that travels the countryside to attract contestants for his chivalrous challenges. Though the advertisements emphasize fairness and honor, the aging knight never loses a match, which sometimes calls his legitimacy into question.

table.name: Taverns and Festivals; Random Tavern Magical Food and Drink
intro: Across the multiverse, the most memorable taverns and festivals provide unique and curious cuisine to their patrons.
You can use the following tables to randomly determine what magical food or drink are available. Unless otherwise specified in the description, the effect of a food or drink lasts for 1 hour.
rows: {@b Beefy Stew}: Your muscles and physique appear lightly oiled and more toned than usual.
{@b Cure What Ale's Ya}: Any pain you have due to open or healing wounds is significantly lessened.
{@b Meat Lover's Pie}: You gain the ability to safely eat and digest raw meat for 12 hours.
{@b Green Tea}: The irises of your eyes turn a vivid green, and your vision is slightly viridescent.
{@b Chocolate Ooze Mousse}: Your skin lightly colors the surface of any metal you touch. The coloration varies depending on the metal but disappears after 1 minute.
{@b Pearl Gray Tea}: For 10 minutes, you exude a gentle aura of nobility, and all of your clothing seems perfectly tailored to you and clean, made from quality cloth, leather, and metal.
{@b Many Mushroom Stroganoff}: You temporarily grow an additional finger.
{@b Red Robin Wine}: You can whistle with amazing clarity and pitch, but only bird calls.
{@b Spicy Quipper Sandwich}: Your nose focuses on detecting blood, making everyone around you smell metallic.
{@b White as Snow Wine}: Your skin grows cold and clammy with fractal snowflake patterns on it, and your breath becomes visible.
{@b Starry Salad}: For 12 hours, you can see stars and constellations in the sky even during daytime or cloudy weather.
{@b Whisper Whiskey}: When you bellow or yell, your voice is only heard as a soft, breathy whisper. When you talk softly, your voice is heard as boisterously loud shouting.

table.name: Taverns and Festivals; Festival Magical Food and Drink
intro: Across the multiverse, the most memorable taverns and festivals provide unique and curious cuisine to their patrons.
You can use the following tables to randomly determine what magical food or drink are available. Unless otherwise specified in the description, the effect of a food or drink lasts for 1 hour.
rows: {@b Carrot Cake}: Your skin turns bright orange, and if your vision normally requires spectacles, you don't need them.
{@b Beastly Beer}: Your teeth and nails become slightly sharpened, and your vision becomes monochromatic.
{@b Peppered Pepcorn}: You feel compelled to skip, and your weight is halved.
{@b Cinnamon Apple Cider}: You smell strongly of cinnamon, but also need to sneeze frequently.
{@b Blueberry Jam on Blue Bread}: Your lips and nails turn bright blue.
{@b Floating Float}: Your hair stands straight up, and your stomach churns as though you were falling.
{@b Straw-Berry Iced Cream}: Your hair becomes stiff and golden like hay, and your presence deters normal crows, ravens, and other small birds.
{@b Hottest Cocoa}: Steam rises from your skin and softly trails out of your ears. You sweat profusely, no matter what the actual temperature is.
{@b Feelings Fruit Pie}: You have difficulty concealing or restraining your emotions, making them plain to observers.
{@b Marshmallow Mead}: Your skin smells strongly of sugar, becomes oddly soft, and darkens when you get close to flames.
{@b Fish 'n Chipper}: You feel more awake, but also have perpetually damp and pruned skin.
{@b Long Lemonade}: Your hair grows {@dice 1d4} inches, and the tips become bleached yellowish-white.

table.name: Taverns and Festivals; Secrets
intro: At your discretion, you can use the following table to randomly determine a secret that plagues your tavern or festival.
rows: A rare winemaker has suddenly changed their recipe, causing untold hysterics amongst the usual customers—who are now starting to go missing.
An enchantment placed on the business causes many patrons to magically forget their time there once they leave.

The proprietor has significant debt owed to the local thieves' guild. They reluctantly help the guild choose its targets, who are often patrons of their tavern or festival, as they are unable to see another way to repay the debt.
Food provided by the establishment is infused with fey magic, causing a subtle but persistent craving that normal food cannot sate.
The owner is cursed, making it impossible for them to turn a profit on their business due to various freak accidents and sudden expenses.
Food and alcohol served by this proprietor sometimes drain the life of patrons, allowing them to sustain themselves by slightly aging their customers instead.
The employees are united in a plot to murder and usurp the owner, and the owner may or may not be aware and preparing for their attempt.
When this establishment is visited by romantic partners, they seem to inevitably end up arguing and break off their relationship in the coming days.

table.name: Taverns and Festivals; Games and Contests
intro: One of the hallmarks of a good tavern or festival is a quality selection of games and contests that patrons can participate in. Whether these contests require competing against NPCs or luck itself, no carousing montage is complete without a roll of fate's dice. Rewards for winning a game or contest can vary, be it a few coins, bragging rights, free food and drink, trophies, or anything else the competitors agree on.

You can use the table below to randomly determine what type of games the adventurers can find at their current tavern or festival. Consider rewarding your players with inspiration if they decide to take part in the game in real life as well (space, setting, and safety permitting).

If you're using the optional {@variantrule Drunkenness Level|GriffonsSaddlebag2|Drunkenness} rules found on page 274, and a game specifies the effects of inebriation on a character playing it, you can replace the penalty's amount in the game description with your drunkenness level instead. If the creature already suffers a penalty to the ability check required by the game as a result of its level of drunkenness, you only apply the penalty once.
rows: {@b Arm Wrestling}: The competitors must attempt to overpower their opponent, first to 3 points wins. Each round requires a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) contest between both parties, with the higher roll earning a point. If the non-ambidextrous creature uses its non-dominant arm, it has disadvantage on the roll but gains 2 points if it wins that round. If the creature is inebriated, apply a −5 modifier to the roll.

{@b Bull-Riding}: Competitors attempt to remain on the back of a raging bull for as long as possible using only one hand. Each contestant must make a series of Strength ({@skill Animal Handling}) checks with disadvantage. The DC of the check is equal to the bull's Strength score and increases by 1 after each successful check. A creature that rolls a 1 on the check suffers {@damage 2d4} piercing damage from the bull's horns. An inebriated creature has a –5 penalty on each ability check made as part of this contest.

{@b Eating/Drinking Contest}: Up to ten creatures compete by consuming more food or drink than their opponents without retching. This requires a series of Constitution saving throws with increasing DCs, beginning with a DC of 5 and increasing by 3 for each consecutive round. If it's a drinking contest and you're using the {@variantrule Drunkenness Level|GriffonsSaddlebag2|Drunkenness} rules found later in this document, each round is considered to be 4 drinks.

{@b Padded-Fist Brawl}: Two creatures face off using padded gloves in a heavily regulated fight within a boxing ring or similar space. Each creature enters combat as normal, but can only attack using padded unarmed strikes that deal a maximum of 1 bludgeoning damage on a hit. The damage is nonlethal, and no contestant is allowed to wear any armor or be carrying any magical items (provided they can be detected). The winner is determined by which contestant successfully lands 4 strikes first. Inebriated creatures have disadvantage on these unarmed strike attack rolls.

{@b Acrobatic Display}: Any number of competitors attempt to complete an obstacle course as quickly as possible. Each competitor makes 5 consecutive Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) checks. Record each result, adding them together to create a speed score. The contestant with the highest speed score completes the course first and wins the contest. If the creature is inebriated, it has disadvantage on these checks.

entries: {@b Bulette Takes the Liar}: Two or more players each take {@dice 4d6} and a {@dice d20}, placing the d6s in a cup, tankard, or similar vessel. At the start of each round of the game, both players shake and empty their cups to roll their d6s onto the table, using the cup to hide the result from the other player. Choose three of the four d6s to add together, treating any duplicate numbers after the first as if they were a 0. The goal is to score the lowest total possible. For example, if a player rolled two 1s, a 3, and a 6, the player's lowest point total would be 4 (1 + 0 + 3) by dropping the 6. On the count of three, both players use their d20 to reveal the total value of their roll by placing the result face up on the die. The player with the lowest value wins the round, causing the other player to roll a {@dice d6} and gain a number of points equal to the number rolled. A player loses once they have 10 or more points. In the event of a tie, neither player wins the round.

You can choose to lie about the result of your d6s and place any number face up on the {@dice d20} when you reveal your roll totals. When a player loses, they can choose to accuse the other player of lying by saying "Bulette," at which point the accused player reveals their d6s. If the player was telling the truth, the accuser rolls {@dice 2d6}, instead of one, as a result of losing the round. If the player was lying, they roll {@dice 2d6} instead.

rows: {@b Jousting}: Two plate-wearing contestants on horseback charge at one another with a {@item shield|PHB} and {@item lance|PHB}. The contest takes place over a series of rounds. At the start of each round, each contestant must make a Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check—recording the result—followed by an attack roll with the lance against the other contestant. A contestant gains a bonus to its AC for the duration of the round equal to the total of their {@skill Animal Handling} check divided by 5, rounded down. The first contestant to land 3 hits or deal at least 35 piercing damage to the other contestant wins. Damage taken in this way is not subtracted from your hit point total. Inebriated creatures have disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks in this contest.

{@b Singing Contest}: Each competitor must sing a song at the same time as their opponent to see which can either sing louder or put on a better performance. This requires a Constitution ({@skill Performance}) or Charisma ({@skill Performance}) contest between both parties. If the creature is inebriated, it gains a +5 bonus to the roll if it uses Constitution for the check, or suffers a −5 penalty to the roll if it uses Charisma.

table.name: Taverns and Festivals; NPCs
intro: As hubs of information, quests, and free-flowing drink, taverns and festivals are often chock-full of both curious and common individuals. Each one has a history, a personality, and possibly a task they're grappling with.
You can use the following table to help randomly populate the patrons of a given tavern or festival.
rows: {@b Emmin Morningsinger} is an older, stoic elf who often keeps himself busy with his work as an alchemist. He comes off cold when giving directions or making requests because he expects the best from everyone around him.

{@b Nimrielye "Nim" Prylla Ferre} is the bright half-elven leader of the local adventurers guild. Praised from a young age for her leadership skills, she's often the go-to for planning out gatherings.

{@b Lasiquea Dontia} is an elderly gnomish woman who always greets everyone with a large smile. She runs a small but popular sandwich shop nearby that's especially busy at lunchtime. Forever thinking about her customers, she treats each one of them as if they were her own child.

{@b Fentrian "Soothe" Jasper} is a half-elven acolyte from a nearby temple. They help treat sick or drunk patrons and only occasionally attempt to give sermons. Generally pleasant, they only become angry when their deity is spoken ill of.
{@b Gavin Glorychase} is a loud, audacious, and goofy 10-year-old human performer. He shows wisdom beyond his years and has a silver tongue. Despite being seemingly parentless, he appears well off.

{@b Alx Lonespark} tends to surround himself with more books than people but is often more than willing to help anyone who needs it. The young halfling has shown a spark of magical aptitude, but it never seems to become more than just that: a spark.

{@b Kaale} is a virtual wall of a dragonborn with an equally intimidating aura about him. He comes across as standoffish and rough, quick to point out mistakes, but also appreciates a job well done. He has a secret appreciation for sweets.

{@b Remil Twilightmantle} is an older tiefling blacksmith. Her strangely hooved feet and large rounded horns are the results of an old curse, earning her the name of "Ram" from her friends and "Archdevil" from everyone else. She's extremely proud of her smithing skills and enjoys the flames of the forge more than unfamiliar faces.

{@b Xarthion} is a willowy, green-scaled dragonborn. They speak rarely, but with keen insight into humanoid behaviors and mannerisms. Despite their chromatic ancestry, rumor has it that they've never hurt a soul or been fooled by a lie.

{@b Malthia Higgenbalm} dreams of studying wizardry but is mostly preoccupied with her tobacco farm. An insatiably curious but perpetually tired halfling, she takes a significant interest in arcane practitioners when she's not dozing in a corner.

{@b Dannyn Stoutheart} is a dwarf of indeterminate age with a kind smile and immaculate clothing. They rarely drink, but also have a more refined palette. They're always eager to see new adventurers, who often have news of far-off fashion trends.

{@b Balthuria Coalfist} is a stubborn gnome with a severe distrust of foreigners. Typically covered in oil and other mechanical grime from the day's labors, they are a stalwart friend and ally once won over. As a quiet observer, they have a finger on the pulse of the local trade and marketplace gossip.

{@b Adiarel Lifesworn} is a female elf that carries a small assortment of plants with her. She shares an oddly close connection to these plants, whose health and color reflect her own temperament. She occasionally offers seeds or clippings to those who earn her trust.

{@b Sashaa Brightscale} is a female human fisherman renowned by her peers for both work ethic and determination. She has an uncanny sense for knowing where the fish are and what bait they'd respond to on any given day.

{@b Terrowin Caskbow} is a male human who deals in secrets of all kinds. He is a charismatic fence who is excellent at connecting like-minded people—for a price. He has ties to the local thieves' guild and influence over multiple powerful politicians, but no one knows who.

{@b Alistaire Greene} is a human farmer with quite the green thumb—metaphorically and literally. They track rich brown dirt wherever they go, but are pleasant company. No one is sure why or how their hands have turned green because the topic is gently, but firmly, avoided.

{@b Welfrala Heavyhand} is well-known for her brusque responses but seems to save her words for the tavern after a long day in the mines. Once the ale starts being poured, this older dwarf is quick to give thoughtful answers to how her day was.

{@b Harley} is a tiefling that finds great pleasure in practical jokes and harmless pranks. They are beloved for the entertainment they bring as well as their even-handed distribution of humor. They long to someday find someone crafty enough to successfully out-trick or prank them and become a partner in their antics.

{@b Rhonas Grout} is a male half-orc mason and provider of quality sculptures and brick-laying. When he relaxes after work, he enjoys strong ale and laughter. Over the years he's accumulated a number of entertaining stories, though he tends to tell them in a roundabout manner.

{@b Brenton Ashforge} is a quiet human who's often unsure of his own skills, but does his best to meet expectations. It is said he keeps a sketchbook with pages filled with designs of clockwork insects, though he's always denied it exists.

table.name: Taverns and Festivals; Drunked Emotions
intro: You can use the following table to randomly determine how an NPC handles themselves when inebriated.

table.name: Taverns and Festivals; Adventure Hooks
intro: Consider including the following scenarios if you wish to add a potentially lighthearted side quest to your campaign.
rows: After a celebratory night in the local tavern, the party discovers that the building has been transported {@dice 5d20} miles away, trading spots with a different tavern. If the magic responsible can be identified, perhaps it can be reversed.

At the end of a day at a carnival, the party learns that the circus tent, including the people and creatures inside it, has mysteriously vanished. The party is asked to recover them and help ensure that the show can go on.
The party's favorite tavern has no alcohol to serve, as their entire stock has vanished. The business may be forced to close if the barrels are not recovered.
The conflict between two of the festival's performers is driving away business. Since they won't explain the feud, the owner asks the players to help resolve the disagreement instead.
As part of a promotional event, the bartender has hidden numerous bar coasters all around town and is offering a night of free drinks to whoever finds the most.
After winning a stuffed festival prize and then losing it in the crowds, a crying child asks the party for help finding it.

The owner can only offer a single room for the party because one of the last travelers to rent a room vanished without returning their key. If it can be found and returned, the owner offers both rooms free for 3 nights.
Amidst the festivities, the festival's cartpulling oxen have been lost. The host offers free admittance and a piece of free magical food for each party member if they are returned.

The establishment's tables and chairs have succumbed to a drunken brawl, so the owner is hiring adventurers to bring the town's carpenter high quality wood so that replacement furniture can be made. However, the only nearby source of lumber is in a nearby forest that's said to be haunted.

The festival hunting contest appears to be more difficult than ever, as the hunting woods have become inexplicably barren of game. Before it's postponed, the huntmaster requests adventurers venture into the woods to see why the wildlife are avoiding the area.

The city's most popular storyteller, a wizened old bard, is refusing to perform in the city's taverns. None of the owners understand why the performer is ignoring them, and tensions between the businesses are rising.

The festival's jousting event threatens to be canceled due to the disappearance of the local ferrier. Most contestants suspect foul play, with the heaviest suspicion being placed upon the current champion.

table.name: Taverns and Festivals; Scavengers' Smorgasbord Encounter Table
intro: When a festival moves, it leaves behind an enormous amount of waste and detritus. This results in a loose following of scavengers and animated creatures that can be found around the festival, waiting for its departure to herald their next meal. Magical remains can sometimes attract more dangerous creatures, or even pass on some of their magical properties to the creatures that find them. These same creatures are equally likely to lurk in the shadows around a busy tavern, providing unexpected combat opportunities for the people who frequent them.
You can use the following table to help determine special random encounters for your adventurers while they visit a tavern or festival.
rows: {@dice 2d4} {@creature awakened shrub|MM|awakened shrubs} ({@chance 50|50%}), {@dice 1d3} {@creature awakened tree|MM|awakened trees} ({@chance 40|40%}), or a {@creature shambling mound|MM} ({@chance 10|10%})
{@dice 1d4} {@creature mimic keg|GriffonsSaddlebag2|mimic kegs} (see Fabulous Feasts Stat Blocks) ({@chance 50|50%}) or {@creature mimic|MM|mimics} ({@chance 50|50%})

{@dice 1d6} {@creature giant rat|MM|giant rats} ({@chance 20|20%}), {@dice 1d4} {@creature hyena|MM|hyenas} ({@chance 20|20%}), {@dice 1d6} {@condition boar|MM|boars} ({@chance 50|50%}), {@dice 2d4} {@creature vulture|MM|vultures} ({@chance 20|20%}), or {@dice 2d3} {@creature swarm of ravens|MM|swarms of ravens} ({@chance 20|20%})

{@dice 1d3} {@creature ale elemental|GriffonsSaddlebag2|ale elementals} (see Fabulous Feasts Stat Blocks) or {@creature wine elemental|GriffonsSaddlebag2|wine elementals} (see Fabulous Feasts Stat Blocks)

{@dice 1d2} {@creature refuse golem|GriffonsSaddlebag2|refuse golems} (see Fabulous Feasts Stat Blocks) ({@chance 40|40%}), {@dice 1d3} {@creature black pudding|GriffonsSaddlebag2|black puddings} ({@chance 20|20%}), {@dice 1d4} {@creature purple jam|GriffonsSaddlebag2|purple jams} (see Fabulous Feasts Stat Blocks) ({@chance 20|20%}), or {@dice 2d3} {@creature gray ooze|GriffonsSaddlebag2|gray oozes} ({@chance 20|20%})
{@dice 1d4} {@creature rot monster|GriffonsSaddlebag2|rot monsters} (see Fabulous Feasts Stat Blocks)

table.name: Grymclover Forests; Corruptive Influence
intro: The manipulative energy that corrupts a forest into a grymclover one can linger for centuries, if not longer. Such twisted magic can wrack the minds of travelers with doubts and fears. Characters within a forest must succeed on a DC 13 Intelligence saving throw whenever they finish a long rest or suffer from an effect from the Corruptive Influence table below. A character has disadvantage on saving throws against these effects if it is within 3 miles of a gateway to the plane of the Fey or the realm of shadows and dread. A corruptive influence lasts until the creature finishes a long rest or is targeted by the {@spell greater restoration|PHB} spell or similar magic.
rows: Your senses betray you, making it difficult to accurately judge or feel confident of your surroundings. For the duration, you have disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks and Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) checks.

Your feelings of aggression and mistrust are heightened. For the duration, you gain the following flaw, "I can only trust myself. If someone crosses me, I will defend myself by whatever means necessary."
You are overcome with sorrow and grief, threatening your hope and sense of self. For the duration, you have disadvantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.

You have the overwhelming feeling of being watched from the shadows at all times, preventing you from recovering from a short rest. For the duration, whenever you expend a Hit Die to regain hit points, roll the die twice and use the lower result.

table.name: Grymclover Forests; Corrupted Creatures
intro: Beasts, monstrosities, and even plants that venture into a grymclover forest will sometimes become suffused by the area's corrupting magic, twisting them with mystifying effects. At your discretion, you can use the following table to determine how a creature may have been warped by the corruption.
rows: The creature can use a bonus action to turn {@condition invisible}, as if by the {@spell invisibility} spell.
The creature can use an action to cast a 1st-level spell at will, such as {@spell bane}, {@spell entangle}, {@spell inflict wounds}, or {@spell magic missile}.
The creature regains 5 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point. If the creature takes radiant damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of its next turn.

The creature is covered in dense brambles, which grant it a +2 bonus to AC and deals {@damage 1d6} piercing damage to any creature that {@action grapple|PHB|grapples} it or is {@condition grappled} by it at the start of each of its turns.

The creature has telepathy out to 120 feet and is aware of the presence of creatures within that range that have an Intelligence score of 4 or higher. It knows the distance and direction to each creature.

The creature has increased pain tolerance, gaining 30 temporary hit points whenever it finishes a short or long rest. If another creature hits it with a melee attack while it has these hit points, the attacker takes 5 necrotic damage.

table.name: Grymclover Forests; Grymclover Navigation DCs
intro: Finding your way through a forest that's been mutated like this is exceptionally difficult due to the dense brambles, thick canopy, and low visibility. When a character makes a Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check to navigate to a specific location within the forest, consult the {@table Grymclover Forests; Grymclover Navigation DCs|GriffonsSaddlebag2|Grymclover Navigation DCs} table. On a failed check, they become lost and suffer a setback determined by the {@table Grymclover Forests; Becoming Lost|GriffonsSaddlebag2|Becoming Lost} table.
rows: A location on the outskirts of the wood, or near a larger settlement
A location near the center of the forest or steeped in Corruption, like most dungeons and ruins are
A location that is lost or hidden, such as a portal to the Fey or Shadow planes, a secret settlement, or a magically cloaked dungeon or ruin

table.name: Grymclover Forests; Becoming Lost
intro: Finding your way through a forest that's been mutated like this is exceptionally difficult due to the dense brambles, thick canopy, and low visibility. When a character makes a Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check to navigate to a specific location within the forest, consult the {@table Grymclover Forests; Grymclover Navigation DCs|GriffonsSaddlebag2|Grymclover Navigation DCs} table. On a failed check, they become lost and suffer a setback determined by the {@table Grymclover Forests; Becoming Lost|GriffonsSaddlebag2|Becoming Lost} table.
rows: Completely lost, the party gets turned around and ends the day at the edge of the forest where they initially entered.
Confused and wandering, the party ends the day up to {@dice 2d4} miles in a random direction away from their intended destination for that day.
Despite getting lost, the party recovers and ends the day only {@dice 1d4} miles away from their intended destination for that day.

table.name: Grymclover Forests; Corrupted Foraged Food and Drink
intro: The adverse effects that cause a grymclover forest to emerge provide additional danger by corrupting sources of clean water and food. A foraging character makes a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check. There's a {@chance 50|50 percent} chance that any food or water found in these forests has been corrupted. A DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) or Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check or {@spell detect poison and disease} spell reveals if any foraged food or water has been corrupted. A creature that ingests corrupted food or water in this way must roll on the Corrupted Foraged Food and Drink table.
rows: The creature is {@condition poisoned} for {@dice 3d4} hours, even if they would normally be immune to the {@condition poisoned} condition.
The creature is {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour, even if they would normally be immune to the {@condition poisoned} condition.
The creature gains no beneficial effects from the food or water but suffers no other ill effects.

table.name: Grymclover Forests; Example Grymclover Jungle Random Encounter Table
rows: An arch of slowly-shifting brambles that acts as a gateway to the plane of the Fey ({@chance 50|50%}) or the plane of Shadow ({@chance 50|50%}) during a waxing crescent moon or new moon, respectively.
A {@creature grymhare|GriffonsSaddlebag2} (see Grymclover Stat Blocks) innocently lying in a stray sunbeam to lure in unwary prey.
A circle of {@dice 4d4} {@creature druid|MM|druids} that are developing a ritual to channel ({@chance 75|75%}) or cleanse ({@chance 25|25%}) the Grymclover Forest's corruption.

{@dice 1d10} {@creature gray ooze|MM|gray oozes} ({@chance 45|45%}), {@dice 1d6} {@creature ochre jelly|MM|ochre jellies} ({@chance 35|35%}), or {@dice 1d3} {@creature black pudding|MM|black puddings} ({@chance 20|20%}) milling about aimlessly.

{@dice 1d4} corrupted, predatory beasts ({@chance 60|60%}) native to the region, such as {@creature bear|MM|bears} or {@creature wolf|MM|wolves}, or corrupted dinosaurs ({@chance 40|40%}) like {@creature triceratops} or {@creature tyrannosaurus rex} (see {@table Grymclover Forests; Corrupted Creatures|GriffonsSaddlebag2|Corrupted Creatures} sidebar above).

The brambles of the forest encircle the party to impede travel. Each character must succeed on a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 2d6} piercing damage and gain one level of {@condition exhaustion} from the constricting vegetation.

{@dice 1d10} {@creature bramble creeper|GriffonsSaddlebag2|bramble creepers} (see Grymclover Stat Blocks) ({@chance 50|50%}) or {@dice 2d8} {@creature archer flower|GriffonsSaddlebag2|archer flowers} (see Grymclover Stat Blocks) ({@chance 50|50%}) patiently waiting in ambush.

{@dice 3d4} {@creature awakened shrub|MM|awakened shrubs} ({@chance 40|40%}), {@dice 1d10} {@creature awakened tree|MM|awakened trees} ({@chance 30|30%}), or {@dice 1d4} {@creature shambling mound|MM|shambling mounds} ({@chance 30|30%}) originally made from the forest's natural plant life, but now corrupted by the forest's choking brambles.

{@dice 2d12} {@creature psybird|GriffonsSaddlebag2|psybirds} (see Grymclover Stat Blocks) ({@chance 50|50%}) or {@dice 1d4} {@creature cloverback toad|GriffonsSaddlebag2|cloverback toads} (see Grymclover Stat Blocks) ({@chance 50|50%}) stirring up mist and fog with their movements.

A {@creature grym-mage tyrannosaur|GriffonsSaddlebag2} (see Grymclover Stat Blocks) ({@chance 50|50%}) or {@dice 1d8} {@creature cyglop|GriffonsSaddlebag2|cyglops} (see Grymclover Stat Blocks) ({@chance 50|50%}) hunting and scavenging, respectively.

The swirling mists thicken and grow acidic for the next {@dice 1d4} hours. At the end of each hour, a character must succeed on a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 4d8} acid damage unless they are protected by shelters such as a tent, building, or another fog-proof barrier.

An unexpected dungeon or ruin (see {@table Grymclover Forests; Example Dungeons Table|GriffonsSaddlebag2|Example Dungeons Table}) that is younger than the forest's corruption ({@chance 80|80%}) or is the origin of it ({@chance 20|20%}).

table.name: Grymclover Forests; Example Dungeons Table
rows: A spiraling, spiked tower built by a legendary necromancer, such as Dendallen ({@link saddleb.ag/dendallen}), or an ancient {@creature lich}.
Roving bands of mindless undead loosely controlled by {@creature wight|MM|wights}, an inexperienced necromancer, or other powerful undead.
The grove and accompanying settlement of an old {@creature druid} circle that worshipped a wrathful, primeval god of nature.
Acolyte {@creature druid|MM|druids} follow the footsteps of their spiritual or literal ancestors, working to summon an avatar of their deity to the Material Plane.
A complex of huts and cottages belonging to a coven of {@creature green hag|MM|green hags} that dabbled in magic forbidden even by others of their kind.
One or more young {@creature green hag|MM|green hags} or {@creature dryad|MM|dryads} tapping into the corruptive enchantment for power and knowledge.
The lair of a powerful {@creature ancient green dragon} trained in druidic magic.
A mixture of {@creature kobold|MM|kobolds}, {@creature cultist|MM|cultists}, and {@creature cult fanatic|MM|cult fanatics} attempting to resurrect a long-dead dragon by any means necessary.
The ruined capital city of a nation of ambitious elves that delved too deeply into the arcane and druidic magic of ecological transmutation.
Various hostile plant life and even some sentient plant creatures nourished and empowered by the residual corruption of the forest.
A sprawling and decrepit estate manor, where a cruel {@creature vampire} reigned by blood and terror.
A group of {@creature vampire|MM|vampires} and their surviving spawn have fled from crusaders, plotting and preparing their vengeance.
A camp from which a terrifyingly large and vicious {@creature gnoll} band terrorized a vast swathe of the surrounding region.
{@creature Bandit|MM|Bandits} or other scavengers are using the dungeon as their base of operations, but the forest's magic is causing them to mutate.
Ruins containing a still partly active summoning circle, where an infamous diabolist released dozens of devils and demons into the world.
A jagged tear in reality itself is allowing various fiends to cross from the Lower Planes onto the Material Plane, potentially heralding a massive invasion on the horizon.

variantrule.name: Drunkenness Level
entries: Drinking alcohol is a common pastime and element of many social encounters. However, consuming too much alcohol causes a creature to become drunk. At the GM's discretion, this drunkenness can be measured in six levels using the following rules. A creature gains one level of drunkenness whenever it has a number of alcoholic drinks within 1 hour equal to 2 + half its Constitution modifier, rounded up (a minimum of 2 drinks per hour).

While a creature has at least one level of drunkenness, it gains a bonus to saving throws it makes against being {@condition frightened} equal to its level of drunkenness, and the DC required to intimidate it increases by the same amount. However, the creature also suffers a penalty to certain rolls equal to its drunkenness level. The kinds of rolls that suffer these penalties, as well as other effects of drunkenness, are shown in the table below.

entries.caption: Drunkenness Level Table
rows: Penalty to Wisdom ({@skill Insight} and {@skill Perception}) checks
Penalty to Strength and Dexterity saving throws, as well as Constitution saving throws to maintain concentration
Penalty to ability checks that don't use Charisma
Penalty to attack rolls and Charisma checks
Speed halved, can't concentrate on spells
{@condition Unconscious}, and can't remember the events of the last hour.

entries: A creature suffers the effect of its current level of drunkenness as well as all lower levels. For example, a creature suffering level 2 drunkenness has a −2 penalty to Wisdom ({@skill Insight} and {@skill Perception}) checks, Strength and Dexterity saving throws, and Constitution saving throws to maintain concentration. However, it also gains a +2 bonus to saving throws against being {@condition frightened}, and its DC to resist being intimidated increases by 2.

Certain creatures have a tolerance to alcohol that's either natural or practiced. A creature that has resistance to poison damage or has advantage on saving throws against poison must drink twice the amount of alcohol as normal to gain one level of drunkenness. A creature immune to poison damage or the {@condition poisoned} condition can't become drunk against their will. Alternatively, at the GM's discretion, a creature may need to drink additional alcohol to gain levels of drunkenness as a result of building up a natural tolerance from drinking it frequently over time.

When a conscious creature starts its turn with level 6 drunkenness, it must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature falls {@condition unconscious}. On a success, the creature spends its action that turn retching and reeling. When it does, the creature loses 1 level of drunkenness. The DC for this saving throw increases by 5 each time the creature repeats the save before it loses all of its levels of drunkenness.

For every hour the creature doesn't drink any alcohol, it loses one level of drunkenness, provided it's either {@condition unconscious} or has also ingested some food or water. Finishing a long rest removes any levels of drunkenness unless the creature fell {@condition unconscious} for the duration of the rest as a result of suffering level 6 drunkenness. In that case, the creature loses {@dice 1d4} + 2 levels of drunkenness instead and doesn't regain Hit Dice as a result of finishing a long rest.
